docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors may soon be able to rejuvenate weakly pumping hearts by creating brand-new muscle and blood vessels fashioned from cells scavenged elsewhere in patients' bodies, new research suggests. The idea is to repair the hearts of people with congestive heart failure, a condition that afflicts nearly five million Americans, by recreating heart tissue damaged by heart attacks and the wear and tear of aging.

headline.main: Transplanting Muscle Cells to Energize Heart

docs.abstract: New research suggests doctors may soon be able to rejuvenate weakly pumping hearts by creating brand-new muscle and blood vessels fashioned from cells scavenged elsewhere in patients' bodies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Another good reason to floss? Severe gum disease, already linked to an increased risk of heart attack, now appears to play a role in strokes.

headline.main: When Diseased Gums Can Cause Strokes

docs.abstract: Severe gum disease appears to play role in strokes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When it is time to choose a surgeon, given the choice between young and inexperienced and older and seasoned, most patients would probably choose the latter. But for at least one procedure, a new study argues, they would be wrong.

headline.main: Artery Cleaning and What Spells Success

docs.abstract: New study of carotid endarterectomies--operations in which plaque is removed from artery in neck to reduce risk of stroke--finds that the longer a surgeon has been in practice, the worse the outcome (S)
docs.snippet: When it is time to choose a surgeon, given the choice between young and inexperienced and older and seasoned, most patients would probably choose the latter.    But for at least one procedure, a new study argues, they would be wrong.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Linda Prine, a physician with a family practice in Manhattan, openly supports abortion rights. She has signs and buttons around her office saying so, and she tells her patients that she works one day a week at a Planned Parenthood abortion clinic. So it may come as no surprise to Dr. Prine's patients that she plans to provide the newly approved abortion pill mifepristone, or RU-486. But patients may not expect the reaction they will get if they call her office and say they want a pill-induced abortion. Wary about abortion opponents, Dr. Prine plans to set up a system that she learned from doctors who provided mifepristone in clinical trials.

headline.main: Wary Doctors Spurn New Abortion Pill

docs.abstract: Danco Laboratories, distributor of abortion pill RU-486 (mifepristone), is about to begin shipping drug, but many physicians still have no plans to offer it to their patients; they would leave it to abortion clinics to provide pill, but many doctors at abortion clinics say they will advise their patients to choose surgical abortion instead because they think surgery is better method; their decision to offer mifepristone, some say, is dictated more by competitive reasons than by their conviction that it is best way to end pregnancy; photos of Dr Deborah Oyer and Dr Linda Prine (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Single Woman-Marred Man Syndrome,'' by Dr. Richard Tuch, (Jason Aronson Inc., $30). Was Monica Lewinsky a naive victim of Bill Clinton, the older man, the self-destructive sex-addict and predatory male? Or was Ms. Lewinsky an insatiable young woman determined to win the affection of another woman's man at whatever cost? How could Mr. Clinton have risked losing all he had by engaging in the affair? Why had Ms. Lewinsky not realized that the relationship was doomed before it even began?

docs.lead_paragraph: It is fairly well established that students who feel the most connected to school exhibit the fewest behavior problems, like truancy, violence and drug use. But figuring out which students feel alienated and how to reach them is another matter. A new study, in this month's Pediatrics, offers some insight. Dr. Andrea E. Bonny, a specialist in adolescent medicine at the Children's Hospital Medical Center of Cincinnati, says she has pinpointed some warnings, including smoking, drinking and lack of interest in school activities.

headline.main: Stopping School Trouble Before It Starts

docs.abstract: New study offers some insight into which students are at highest risk for developing behavioral or health problems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The CT scan shows a spot on your liver.'' It was a stunning announcement from a surgeon walking me through the plan for dealing with a different situation, the colon cancer that had returned after less than a year. My heart was now sharing shoes with my feet.

headline.main: M.S./Cancer Combo No. 13 And the Coping Mind Game

docs.abstract: Richard M Cohen describes his personal experiences in learning to cope with adversity, first struggling for years with multiple sclerosis, and then coping with colon cancer and its recurrence (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors say they have found a link between cigarette smoking and ruptured aneurysms, the sudden, devastating medical condition that leaves 60 percent of its sufferers dead or disabled. The finding, published in the September issue of The Journal of Neurosurgery, may help surgeons decide when to operate on small intracranial aneurysms. Surgery can save lives but carries risk.

headline.main: A Deadly Link: Smoking and Aneurysms

docs.abstract: Doctors find link between cigarette smoking and ruptured aneurysms, sudden, devastating medical condition that leaves 60 percent of its sufferers dead or disabled (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In January 1964, when the surgeon general of the Public Health Service issued the first report on smoking and health, linking tobacco to a host of serious diseases, including and especially lung cancer, the most common statement from the many smokers I interviewed was, ''By the time I get lung cancer, they'll know how to cure it.'' Well, it is nearly 37 years later, and ''they'' still don't know how to cure lung cancer, except when the disease is detected before symptoms develop and while the tumor is still at its site of origin, a small minority of cases.

headline.main: Lung Cancer Cure? Try Prevention Instead

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on lung cancer; says doctors still do not know how to cure lung cancer except when disease is detected before symptoms develop and while tumor is still at its site of origin; doctors do know how to prevent 90 percent of cases of lung cancer--by not smoking; chart (M)
